head.title: Kramnik Holds 1-Point Lead After Another Tense Draw

hedline.hl1: Kramnik Holds 1-Point Lead After Another Tense Draw

abstract.p: Robert Byrne Chess column on Game 6 of world chess championship between Garry Kasparov and Vladimir Kramnik, which ends in draw; diagram (M)

block.p: Garry Kasparov and Vladimir Kramnik fought a grim battle to a 66-move draw in Game 6 of their world championship chess match in London yesterday. The early tide of the game saw Kramnik press hard to produce a mating attack, but Kasparov forced exchanges of material that pulled him through what looked like the worst. But it wasn't.
Kramnik mobilized his rooks and came in for a strike on the other wing. It was enough to revive the pressure that the challenger seemed to have lost earlier.

Garry Kasparov and Vladimir Kramnik fought a grim battle to a 66-move draw in Game 6 of their world championship chess match in London yesterday. The early tide of the game saw Kramnik press hard to produce a mating attack, but Kasparov forced exchanges of material that pulled him through what looked like the worst. But it wasn't.
Kramnik mobilized his rooks and came in for a strike on the other wing. It was enough to revive the pressure that the challenger seemed to have lost earlier.
It looked for a long time as if Kramnik was going to take this game, but a clever maneuver with queen and knight forced chances of perpetual check that Kramnik couldn't stop.

Kasparov accepts the Queen's Gambit again, despite his troubles in Game 4. But Kramnik, feeling sure that Kasparov has found improvements in the endgame following 7 dc Qd1 8 Rd1 Bc5, goes back to Botvinnik's old favorite, 7 a4, preventing any thought of a black advance with . . . b5.

Black's counterattacking prospects are diminished, but White has a hole at b4 beckoning intruders. After 11 Nc3, Black has to reckon with the space-gaining 12 d5, and thus moves to block it with 11 . . . Nd5. Kramnik likes the thrust with 13 h4, which sets up a dangerous gambit after 13 . . . Bh4 14 Nh4 Nc3 15 bc Qh4 16 Re3 to be followed by 17 Rg3. Kasparov refuses to oblige him.

Kramnik's 17 h6 loosened the dark squares in the black kingside, and he brought his queen knight to mass for an attack with 18 Ne4. After 18 . . . Nc7 19. Nc5, Kramnik charged in with 19 Nc5 Bd5 20 Ra3, but after Kasparov's 20 . . . Nc6! 21 Bd5 Qd5, the threat was 22 . . . Bc5, winning material.

Kramnik defended with 22 Ncd7 Rad8 (not 22 . . . Nd4? because of 23 Qg4) 23 Nc6 Rd7 24 Ne7 Ree7, but after 25 Rc3 f6 26 Be3 the white pressure had evaporated. Still, Kramnik had another card to play: control of the open c line.

Kramnik had enough rook pressure to force the exchange with 31 . . . Rc5 32 dc, thus creating a healthy passed c pawn out of the former isolated d4 pawn. And it was not long before Kramnik's rook took a hearty grip on the open d line with 37 Rd1 and 39 Rd6.
Kramnik leads the 16-game match, 3 1/2-2 1/2. Game 7 is tomorrow.
